listWit.witness: London, British Museum Royal 10 A I

editorialDecl.p: Encoding of this text has followed the recommendations of the LombardPress 1.0.0 guidelines for a critical edition.

change.p: File Started for the first time.

div.p:
Quidam tamen de suo sensu gloriantes
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 43
, after the postquam Master determined above about the omnipotence of God through its relation to the being of things produced, now in distinction 43 he considers omnipotence through its to quantity or numerousness of these produced things.

And it is divided in three parts because in the first place he refutes one falsifying opinion, in the second place he addresses and solves this opinion's sophistical argument, in the third place he offers his own true determination. The second beings at
non potest Deus
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 43
. The third begins at
fateamur itaque Deum
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 43
.
The second part has seven parts which he uses to address this false. The parts are clear from reading. And this is the division in general.
Whether that which God preordained that he himself would immediately do he is freely able to not do in the future.

That not because nothing is able to be done by God, therefore. The consequence is valid because the conclusion supposes the opposite. The antecedent is proved because, if this were so, then it follows that every creature is possible because is able to make it, just as therefore a house is able to be made by man because man is an artifact knowing how and able to make a house. An the consequence is clear for a similar reason because therefore an impossible a is not able to made by God because such a impossible thing is not able to be made possible or to occur.

In the second place, if the question were true, it would follow that, even that which God did not preordain that he would do, he would be able to do. The consequence is clear from a similar reason, but the consequent is false. The proof is because then God would be able to produce something infinite, since there does not seem to a be a greater reason for one non-preordained thing than for another to be to be in the future.

In the third place, it is inconvenient not to be done by a prudent man because he preordained and fore-said that he would do it and because if were to act justly and decently, then he would do it, therefore it would be inconvenient for God not to do what he preordained that he would do, and consequently this is impossible. The last consequence is clear through Anselm because the smallest inconvenience is impossible in God.

In opposition is the saying of Christ,
I have the power of the give up my soul or take it up again
, but he had pre-ordained to give up his soul for all and yet he was freely able to rescue it and keep it from pain and death, therefore what he preordained that he would do he is able not to do.
This is confirmed because whatever God preordained that he would do, he preordained this
contingently and freely, therefore he will do this contingently and freely, therefore he would be able to never do this, therefore the question is true.

First conclusion: though God therefore is not able to produce impossible a into existince because it is impossible for a to be produced into existnce, nevertheless therefore producible b is able to be because God is able to produce b into existnce. The first part is proved because, if not, then it follows that the converse is true, therefore a is not able to be because God is not able to produce a. But this is false because this would imply an insufficiency indeed an insufficient of the power of God, therefore. The last consequence is clear because through this it is indicated that the first cause and ratio of this impossibility would be the negation of power in God and a defect with respect to the power required for producing this. Example: if therefore the sun is not able to illuminate beyond the heavens or below the closed house because this place is not an illuminable place or because there is a obstacle through an opaque body, and yet there is no defect of power attributed to the sun. This is confirmed because, if therefore vision is not able to see sound because sound is not visible and therefore not conversely for a similar reason, therefore God is not able, etc. to produce and impossible a. The second part of the conclusion is proved because it says, b is, therefore it is because God gave being to it; therefore this is true as long b is able to exist; therefore it is able to exist because God is able to give being to it; therefore the whole conclusion is true. This is confirmed through
Anselm in De casu diaboli, who says in chapter 12 ,
therefore the world is because God was able to make the word before it became, not because the world itself was previously able to be
. From these words the second part is able to be known.

First corollary: though every makeable things is able to be produced effectively by God acting alone, nevertheless God is not able by himself to produce effectively every makable thing according to its every condition and denomination. The first part was clear in the preceding conclusion. The second part is proved because he is not able to produce a meritorious act with a condition of respect or relation which implies a contradiction, therefore. The antecedent is clear because to be meritorious is a condition of an act as related to some relatable cause while acting in conformity to a divine rule Again, a meritorious act indicates a relation to something freely accepting such an act for a certain reward, therefore as such it is not able to be produced by God acting alone.

Second corollary: that therefore God is not able to make contradictories true at the same time because these things are from their own natures formally repugnant. This is clear because it would be useless to assign an extrinsic cause for their repugnance and impossibility since they are impossible and repugnant from their own quiddities.

Third corollary: though the impossibility of producing impossible a comes from the nature of the producible or impossible thing, nevertheless the impossibility of sinning does not come from the nature of sin but from the sinless nature of God. The first part is clear through things that have been said The second part is proved because the occurrence of sin is made possible by the creature, therefore its impossibility should not be assigned to the nature of sin by which it is impossible that God sins. but rather he is not able to sin because he is the highest perfection and necessary goodness without any wickedness. From which it would be able to be inferred that, though a is possible therefore it is able to exist because God is omnipotent, nevertheless impossible b is not therefore able to exist because God is not omnipotent. Again, it follows that it is more convenient to say therefore man is not able to be an ass because God does not wish that he is so than to say God is not able to make it so. This is clear because the second statement
indicates an imperfection in God and the first does not.

Second conclusion: though God through his immeasurable power is able to produce something infinitely perfect in the genus of an accident, nevertheless he is not able to produce or make something of infinite perfection absolutely in the genus of substance. The first part is proved because God is able to produce a whiteness which would be an infinitely perfect whiteness, and nevertheless would not be an infinitely perfect accident nor an infinitely perfect being absolutely, therefore. The antecedent is proved because this does not seem to conclude a contradiction,
as was proved above about the production of charity through proportional parts etc in the preceding question, when arguing in the against the second conclusion
. The second part is proved because a substance of infinite perfection absolutely would be absolutely independent, and consequently would be God, but God is not able to produce another God outside himself, therefore.

The first corollary: it is the case that a is infinitely perfect whiteness and a is not an infinitely perfect quality. This is clear because, if a were infinite whiteness in the geneus of quality, then charity b would be a more perfect quality than a because it would be of a superior species.
Second corollary: with the intension of perfection in species the remitted perfection in the genus stands in the same. This is clear through the same.

Third corollary: it is the case that something is more distant from the non-grade of its own species than it is from the non-grade of perfection absolutely or from the non-grade of being. This is clear because, if a were infinite whiteness, then this would infinitely distant from the non-being of whiteness, and nevertheless would not infinitely but finitely distant from the non-grade of being or perfection absolutely. From this it is clear that these perfections are not able at the same to be uniformally remitted through certain measure up to non-grade. This is clear because then one would be able to be without the other, which is impossible. And the deduction is clear.

Third conclusion: just as God is able to never have wished that which he willed from eternity, so God is able to never produce that which he ordained that he would do. The first part is clear through what has been said in other questions. This is confirmed because he wills freely and contingently, therefore he is able not to will, to the fact that God is able not to will it follows that he is able to never have willed, therefore. The second part of the conclusion is proved from the first part because his will is effectively his doing, therefore just as he is able not to will that which he wills, so he is able to never produce that which he preordained that he would do. It is confirmed, the created will freely and contingently produced his act, therefore the divine will also when it acts externally. The consequence is clear since the ratio of freedom and contingency of a creature is rooted and founded in the divine liberty, and the antecedent we experience because we perceive that we are able to will what we will or what we do not will or conversely able to not will what we will or what we do not will.

The first corollary: to the fact that God necessarily wills that the antichrist will be, it follows that all things occur, not contingently, but from necessity. This is clear because according to the Master since his will is omnipotent, it follows that if he wishes a, then a will necessarily be. But the same argument applies regarding any future, therefore etc. This is confirmed because, if future a occurs contingently, having supposed that God wishes that this will be necessarily, this will seem to be therefore because second causes would freely and contingently produce a into being, but this is false because the same necessity and in the same mode by which God wishes this future will be he wills these causes influence or concur for the production of this with the same necessity. Again, if these causes produced freely, it follows also that God produces and wishes freely
The consequence is clear from what has been said since freedom of the second cause depends on the first liberty and the divine will.

Second corollary: just as when God acting or creating efficiently f is himself not changed from when he was not creating, so when he wishes necessarily that which he wished contingently this varies in no way. This is clear because that at this moment God wishes a freely with the freedom of contradiction, and that afterwards on account of lapse of time he wishes the same thing necessarily does not mean that God is intrinsically disposed differently, but only through some extrinsic denomination, just as was made clear above in the example of the example of the statue, for according to the
Master, in distinction 41 of book one
Lombardus, Sent., I, d. 41, xxx
, God retained diverse denominations for himself on account of extrinsic mutations.

Third corollary: though to the position or the pastness of a thing in being it follows necessarily that God wills that this things was, nevertheless through the position or pastness of this thing it is not inferred that God is necessitated to this. This is clear because then the creature would have priority and causality with respect to God, just as necessary things with respect to their necessity, which should not be said.
From what has been said the affirmative part of the question is clear which is clear from the third conclusion

Against the first conclusion, it is argued in the first place thus, that which is able to be, therefore is able to be because or some cause is able to make it, therefore. Therefore impossible a is not able to be because God is not able to make it. And the consequence is clear because in convertible causes, if affirmative, then it is the cause of affirmation and negation of a negation, as is held
in book one of the Posterior Analytics
Aristoteles, Posteriora Analytica, I, xxx
.

In the second place, that which is suitable to God from eternity and necessarily does not suit him because it suits creatures. But that God does not produce impossible b is suitable to him from eternity and necessarily, therefore is not suitable through a creature or something extrinsic to himself. The major is proved because either this is a kind of imperfection or a perfection. If the first then it is not suitable to God. If the second, it follows that it is not suitable to him on account of a creature nor through some intelligible thing extrinsic to him. The minor of the argument is known.

In the third place, therefore the creature is not able to corrupt God because God is not able to be corrupted, therefore. Therefore the impossible is not able to be because God is not able to produce it in existence. The consequence holds because in the same mode it seems that it should be said about all impossible things. The antecedent is proved because the necessity of being which is formally a part of God is the reason why a creature is not able to corrupt him rather than a defect in the power of the creature

In the fourth place, it is equally impossible that God commits a sin as it is that he would make a chimera or some other impossible thing. But the reason for the first impossibility comes from the part of God, as corollary one says, therefore the reason for the impossibility of any other thing will also hold from the part of God, not from the part of a creature or the impossibility of a thing. The second part of the antecedent is conceded earlier. This is confirmed because God is the cause of all causes causing repugnance and impossibility, therefore this impossibility holds from the part of God.

Against the second part of this conclusion, if therefore possible a is able to be etc., it follows that God would act and wish externally from eternity and necessarily. The consequent is false. And the consequence is clear because from eternity something possible was possible and it also necessary that God produces possible a indeed that God necessarily wishes possible that possible a is able to be.

In the second place, that the creature is producible from God and that God is productive of this thing are at the same time in nature because they are correlative, therefore one is not the cause of the other. The consequence is clear because a cause is naturally prior to the caused. And the antecedent is clear from itself.

In the third place, something is possible formally
and is not possible for God, therefore not, therefore etc. The antecedent is clear because to be able to err, deceive, cheat are possible things in themselves but not for God, therefore.

In the fourth place, a therefore is not able to be such or disposed in such a way because God is able to make it such or disposed in such a way, therefore, not therefore because God is able to make it to be that is possible The consequence holds because the ratio of denying the consequent is because every possibility is from God. The antecedent is clear because an act is not able to be from God that is deformed, blameworthy, or unworthy of merit, indeed not even denominatively meritorious.

Against the first part of the second conclusion, it is argued because regarding the ratio of anything produced externally or producible its being is finite and limited, therefore any infinity is repugnant to anything produced externally. The consequence is clear because according to the reason that one mode of infinity is suitable to it, by the same reason no mode would be repugnant to it. The antecedent is clear through
Augustine, VI De Trinitate, chapter 5
Augustinus, De Trinitate, VI, c. 5, xxx . Again,
Sapientia 7
Lord you have constituted all things with number, weight, and measure.
Sapientia 11:21
.

In the second place, it follows that God with respect to something producible outside himself would be able to render himself impotent. The consequent is false. And the consequence is clear because, if he were to produce something infinite, then he would not be able afterwards to produce another thing of that ratio. This is clear because anything that would be of this species would be included in the former, otherwise it would not be infinite.

In the third place, if God were to produce infinite love or whiteness, it follows that this would contain an infinity of degrees, and consequently it would be an infinite number. The consequent is impossible, as is clear through what has been said above, every number is equal or unequal and is able to increase through an addition of unity and consequently no infinity is a possible or giveable number.

Against the third conclusion: however the divine will is disposed intrinsecally with respect to future a, in some way it is now disposed with respect to it. But whenever it will be disposed to it necessarily then it will also now necessarily wish that a will be. The minor is known because whenever future a will be past God necessarily will wish that a had been. The major is proved in many ways.

In the first place because, if not, it follows that God would be each day less than free than the day before. The consequent is false. The consequence is clear regarding some future that today occurred in the past because today God necessarily wishes that it was and the day before he wished that it was not necessarily but freely, therefore etc.

In the second place, because if not, then it follows that some creature will necessitate the divine will to will. The consequent is false, and the consequence is clear because from the position of a creature it being God would be necessitated to will that creature. Again there is some cause of new necessity therefore this is not the case unless it is a creature.

In the third place, it follows that pure privation and pure nothingness will necessitate the divine will. The consequent should not be said, and the consequence is clear because a past thing is nothing, and nevertheless it leads God to an impossibility and the necessity of willing, therefore.

In the fourth place, the divine will is necessitated from itself with respect to the past, therefore also with respect to the future. The consequence holds because it does not seem to be the ratio of diversity that if it were not to necessitate itself with respect to the past that it would not be able to necessitate itself with respect to the future.

To the first, the consequence is denied, and to the proof it is said that this rule does not hold according to any form and in diverse matters. For it does not follow, and a corruptible therefore is immediately able to be destroyed by God because God is an omnipotent destructive power, therefore because something is not corruptible therefore it is not able to be destroyed or corrupted because God is not an omnipotent destructive power. It is clear that the consequence is not valid because the Holy Spirit is not able to be destroyed, not because God is not an omnipotent destructive force, but because the Holy Spirit is formally a necessary being.
Again, it does not follow, everything that known from eternity to be is thus known from eternity to be because God sees from eternity all future things, therefore what is not known from eternity is not known to be because God does not see all future things.
Again, it does not follow, every bird is able to fly because is an animal furnished with wings, therefore what is not able to fly is thus not able to fly because a winged animal furnished with wings is not able to fly, but rather because it is not able to fly because it is not a winged animal.

In the second place, it is said that negation is the cause of negation if this negation after pure negation denotes affirmation, but in the proposed it would denote a defect of the power in God which would come from God and not from the object. Likewise this negation would denote that this precise or stronger cause itself comes from God, just as in the affirmative it is noted that such a precise or stronger cause comes from God.

To the second, the major is conceded if the word because denotes causality. But if it is taken loosely, such that it more greatly denies causality that posits it, then the major is denied, and most especially when taking the word to suit loosely for anything that is say-able about God either through the mode of affirmation or of negation or through the assertion about the present, about what exists, or about what is possible.
To the proof, it is said that it does not belong to perfection or imperfection to not be able to do the impossible, because it posits nothing affirmatively but only denies.

To the third, the consequence is denied because somethings are said about God through the mode of impossibility which do not denote or connote an imperfection in God, but rather really and implicitly indicate a perfection of the power in him such that this possibility is equivalent to the necessity of perfection, just as he is not able to be corrupted, he is not able to be impeded, he is not able not to influence the action of a secondary cause. But things said about him through the negation of his power would denote an imperfection, for example the saying that he is not able by himself to produce b. But the mode of impossibility of making a Chimera does not come from an imperfection of his absolute power.

To the fourth, it is said that it is not similar in the case of anything impossible because that he is not able to sin is suitable to God by reason of necessary goodness, therefore this is thus conveniently understood to come from God himself. But the impossibility of producing a Chimera does not denote an imperfection in God, but rather would seem to denote an imperfection if it came from God himself and not principally from the unproducible Chimera.

To the confirmation, it is said that, though God is the remote cause and accidentally and indirectly the cause of impossibility by virtue of the fact that he is a cause in act or the potency of nature from the formal reasons of repugnant things, nevertheless the proposed does not follow on account of this.

To the first against the second part, the consequent is denied because, though the causal proposition properly, if is about something affirmatively in existence in the present, has true causality corresponding in the thing, nevertheless this is not universally required for the truth of any causal hypostate. Whence in the proposed this causal thing does not signify a cause and a propter quid, nor is it about something in existence but rather about something possible, and it does not signify that a cause causes but that a cause is able to cause.

To the second, the consequent would be able to be conceded, as well as the consequence when speaking about proper and true causality. If nevertheless it were understood inconveniently and inferred that such a causal hypostatica were false then the consequence would be denied.

To the third, the antecedent is denied when taking the term possible properly for something producible in itself. To the proof, it is said that sin would be able to be from God. Not only would it imply that some being is able to effectively be from God, but it would imply that something would be able to come from or be omitted by God against the dictate of right reason and against the rule of divine justice with which God ought to be in agreement.

To the fourth, it is said that, if through the word being this being isunderstand through a positive form, then the antecedent is denied. But if this being is understood generally, positively, privatively, absolutely, relatively, then the consequence is denied because whenever a thing is able to be this or in this way, it is not properly the thing that has this potency, but a defect of potency or a defective potency.

In the second place, it is said in agreement to a certain corollary that, just as a meritorious act is not able to effected by God alone on account of the relative condition to a second cause under a determined disposition, so also not in the agreement of the composition is the effect of the second cause able to be from God alone, and thus it is able to be said that God alone, though he is able to produce a meritorious act, nevertheless is not able to produce a meritorious act.

To the first against the second conclusion, the consequence is denied, because if God were to produce an infinite love, then he would still be able to create another because he would be able to destroy the first love and produce another infinite love, indeed he would even be able ton conserve the first in the same place and put with the first both the second and a third as he pleases..

To the third, the consequence is denied because, though perhaps God would be able to produce infinite things, nevertheless not infinite number. The first is clear concerning the production of angels through proportional parts of the hour. The second is clear because the even and odd are an inseparable attribute of number and is able to be increased through unity.

To the first against the third conclusion, the consequence is denied. To the first proof the consequences is similarly denied because he intrinsically wishes today and yesterday the same thing in the same mode.

To the second, the consequence and the consequent are denied. To the proof it is said that, if the world from denotes a connatural connection then it is conceded. But if it denotes causality, then it is denied because such a necessary thing does not have a cause.
To the third, the consequence is denied because this necessity is only connatural.
To the fourth, the consequences is denied because it is necessitated from itself to production of the Holy Spirit and not another thing.

Fateamur itaque Deum
Lombardus, Sent I, d. xxx
, etc. First conclusion: that God is able to make many things which he makes and to will other things which he wishes de facto. See the text in this place and read the arguments and the solutions in the same place.

Second conclusion: that what God makes it is fitting for him to make, and if he were to make other things, it would be fitting for him to make them, and nevertheless his will is not able to be different nor new nor changeable in some way. For though he is able to will that he never willed this, nevertheless he is not able to will a new will; but his will is eternal which he shows in many arguments and authorities. Read the text.
